Award.AwardTitle: UNIQUE ADVANTAGES OF ORGANOMETALLIC SUPPORTING LIGANDS FOR METAL COMPLEXES
Award.AbstractNarration:
Innocent ligands, such as phosphines and cyclopentadienyl derivatives, impart electronic and steric properties once coordinated to the metal center but the ligands themselves are not modified during the course of a chemical transformation. In contrast, non-innocent ligands cooperate with the metal during its reactions. The distinction between these two classes of ligands is becoming blurry and the research team led by Professor Paula Diaconescu at the University of California-Los Angeles seeks to identify and exploit the effect of non-innocent ligands on reactivity, particularly carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bond activation, aromaticity, single molecular magnets and metal-metal interactions. The experimental research team at UCLA collaborates with theoretical and computational scientists at other universities forming an interdisciplinary group focused on tuning the reactivity of the synthesized metal complexes, observing their resultant reactivity patterns, and incorporating unreactive molecules into value-added compounds. The diverse work environment allows for the integration of women and underrepresented minority students while expanding the representation from different ethnic and cultural backgrounds in the scientific enterprise. Professor Diaconescu collaborates with a number of high school students, enabling them to learn advanced experimental techniques as well as to gain an understanding of molecular and materials synthesis and catalysis. Professor Diaconescu continues to work with the California NanoSystems Institute, particularly the High School Nanoscience Program, in partnership with the Los Angeles Unified School District.

This award from the NSF Chemical Synthesis Program supports the research efforts of Professor Paula Diaconescu at the University of California-Los Angeles, in examining the role of ancillary groups as they participate in reactions at rare earth metal centers. The research group is focused on ferrocene-based chelating ligands because they possess unique electronic characteristics that make them especially versatile in supporting the reactivity of the metal centers, especially in relation to (1) the reductive cleavage of C-H/C-fluorine (F) bonds by rare earth metals, (2) aromaticity in arene-bridged rare-earth complexes, (3) inverse sandwiches of arene-bridged paramagnetic lanthanides, and (4) the importance of organometallic supporting ligands.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This grant focused on two groups of supporting ligands for metal complexes: bidentate ferrocene diamides and tetradentate diaryloxides. The first group was important in the synthesis of new organometallic compounds and the discovery of new reaction mechanisms, while the second is relevant to the present project. Several objectives were pursued with the first group: (1) Reductive cleavage of C-H/F bonds by rare earth metals. The scope of this new reaction was expanded and its mechanism studied. (2) Fundamental studies of aromaticity in arene-bridged rare-earth complexes. The range of aromatic substrates was expanded and the reactivity of these complexes was explored. (3) Inverse sandwiches of arene-bridged paramagnetic lanthanides. Single-molecule magnets of paramagnetic lanthanides were developed.

In addition to those objectives, we also explored the redox activity of the ferrocene backbone and its importance in redox switchable catalysis. Notable advancements in this first area include (1) a proof of concept for the first copolymerization reaction controlled by a redox switch; (2) a synthesis of triblock copolymers using redox switchable polymerization; (3) a mechanistic study of aluminum redox switchable polymerization; (4) a proof of concept for the first hydroelementation reaction controlled by a redox switch; (5) an extension of the switchable polymerization concept to olefinic monomers.

Broader impacts: The work supported by the grant aided in the training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers based at UCLA as well as that of students housed by other universities. Several female undergraduate and 3 female graduate (1 URM) students were part of the group. Currently, the group consists of 1 female and 3 male graduate students (2 LGBT) in addition to 9 undergraduate students (4 female). In addition, many high school students had the opportunity to experience research first hand and contribute to various projects.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2017
Modified by: Paula L Diaconescu

In addition to those objectives, we also explored the redox activity of the ferrocene backbone and its importance in redox switchable catalysis.
